ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Magnetic medium broadband metamaterial absorber based on the coupling resonance mechanism

Affiliation.OrgDivision: State Key Laboratory of Explosion Science and Technology
Advanced Composites Centre for Innovation and Science, (ACCIS)

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: In this paper, we present a design, simulation and experimental measurement of a metamaterial absorber (MMA) in the microwave regime. The proposed MMA structure consists of periodic cross electric resonators separated from the ground metal plane using a magnetic composite layer. The broadband absorption can be ascribed to the periodic cross electric resonators. The anti-parallel currents are observed at the peak frequency on the surface of the MMA and the ground metal plane, respectively, and thus the coupled resonance magnetic field occurs in the magnetic medium resulting in the magnetic loss. The new absorption peak located at 2.8 GHz broadens the whole absorption spectrum. The frequency of this peck is lower than that of the cross resonator of 3.7 GHz, suggesting the distinguish resonance mechanism: the absorbing properties are ascribed to the phase cancellation, Ohmic loss, dielectric loss at the end of the cross pattern, and the magnetic loss caused by the above mentioned coupled magnetic field. The obvious absorption peak at 2.8 GHz is also observed experimentally verifying the simulation result. All these results indicate the proposed MMA structure is promising for microwave absorbing application.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: With electromagnetic metamaterials, exotic behaviors such as negative refraction, which are not found in natural materials, can be obtained artificially. Many devices such as sub-wavelength imaging superlens [1, 2], nano-antennas [3, 4], and cloaking [5, 6] have been invented and studied in relevant spectral range from radio [7], microwave [8, 9], mm-Wave [10] to THz [11–13], Mid-IR [14], near-IR [15], and visible [16]. Being artificial medium, the electromagnetic property of MMs can be characterized by the complex electric permittivity, ε(ω)=ε 1+iε 2, and complex magnetic permeability, μ(ω)=μ 1+iμ 2, which can be tailored by the design of the geometry of its unit cells. To date, much of the MMs research has been focused on the realization and adjustment of simultaneously negative permittivity and permeability, resulting in the negative refraction, with practical applications in many areas, such as metamaterials absorbers.

In 2008, Landy et al. [17] proposed an idea to construct engineered electromagnetic metamaterial absorbers (MMA) consisting of electric resonator and cut wire. The complex electric permittivity and complex magnetic permeability can be adjusted independently for the electric and magnetic resonance in certain frequency, resulting in the change of the effective impedance, which is defined as
$Z(\omega) \sqrt{ \mu(\omega) /\varepsilon (\omega)}$ . If the effective impedance matches the free space impedance Z 0, the reflection is minimized. At the same time, if the metamaterials are also of high loss decided by the imaginary part of the permittivity and permeability, then a high absorption can occur [18]. Compared with the traditional magnetic absorber layer, MMA has many advantages. First, electromagnetic parameter can be manipulated individually in certain frequency regime; second, MMA is a kind of light weight diluted medium which can broaden the practical applications especially in the aerospace; third, the fabrication of the MMA in micrometer and millimeter range is simple and low-cost owning to the development of the printed circuit board (PCB) technique. However, most metamaterial absorbers including novel dual-band [19] and triple-band [20] absorbers operate at rather specific narrow frequency range. The broad band metamaterial absorber remains a challenge described as a low Q factor [21, 22] which can be defined as
$Q= (1/R) \sqrt{L/C}$ . Equivalent resistance, capacitance and inductance values, R, C and L, are adjusted in order to achieve the lower Q factor at relevant frequency which leads to a broadband absorption. Numerous works focus on the design of novel configurations and size optimization in order to achieve the broadband or multiband absorption. These metamaterials derive their absorption properties primarily through the dielectric loss, Ohmic loss and the impedance matching for the magnetic and dielectric response at resonance frequency [23]. But to our knowledge the absorber combining MMA with magnetic composite to enhance magneto-absorption at resonance frequency is rarely reported.

In this work, we propose a simple and efficient approach to enhance magnetic loss and to achieve broadband absorber in GHz frequency regime. The proposed absorber is composed of a typical and simple cross resonator MMA configuration in millimeter regime and a nano-ferroferric oxide/epoxy resin magnetic composite layer as supporting and absorbing medium. In contrast to a single magnetic absorbing layer, the absorbing mechanism of the magnetic medium supported MMA structure is more complicated due to the adjustment of both complex permittivity and permeability. Via the design, simulation and measurement, a broadband MMA composite has been obtained with a new loss mechanism based upon the dielectric loss, Ohmic loss occurred at the metal surface and coupled magnetic resonance loss in the composite layer.

Section1.Heading: Design
Section1.Para:
The schematic of the metamaterial absorber unit cells is revealed in Fig. 1(a) and (b), which comprises a cross resonator separated from a metal plane using a nano-ferroferric oxide/epoxy resin magnetic composite layer. The characteristic of the magnetic composite layer was defined by the effective permittivity and permeability shown in Fig. 2. Computer simulations were performed using the commercial finite-difference time domain solver CST Microwave Studio [24]. The program simulated the single unit cell with periodic boundary conditions applied to the side walls parallel to w direction and the open boundary was defined at the front and back surfaces of the unit for the electromagnetic wave incidence and transmission. The simulated MMA had the dimension of a=14 mm, l=12 mm and w=2 mm and the thickness of magnetic composite was b=3 mm. The loss metal for the MMA and ground metal plane was aluminum, the electric conductivity of which is 3.72×107 S/m.
Fig. 1
(a) Schematic structure of the proposed metamaterial absorber unit cell ground with metal plane. (b) The unit cell without ground metal in order to obtain the transmission coefficients
Fig. 2
(a) The effective complex permittivity and (b) complex permeability of the magnetic composite

In order to measure the transmission S 21 and reflection S 11 parameters of the magnetic composite materials, the toroidally shaped sample (outer diameter: 7 mm, inner diameter: 3.04 mm) was measured by means of Vector Network Analyzer (Agilent 8722ES). Using the Nicolson–Ross procedure for the transformation of the load impedance by a transmission line, the effective permittivity and permeability shown in Fig. 2 were determined by the transmission S 21 and reflection S 11 parameters. The microwave reflection response of the model backed with a metal plane was evaluated by using classic transmission line theory [25].

The complex permittivity and permeability shown in Fig. 2 represent the characteristics of the magnetic composite layer. The real part of the permittivity disperses in the range of 16 to 18 at the relatively low frequency and decreases rapidly at 13–18 GHz. The imaginary part of the permittivity increases from 4 to 12 as the frequency increases. The real part of the permeability disperses from 1.15 to 0.05 with increasing frequency indicating that the magnetic response becomes weak with the frequency increase. The imaginary part of the permeability is about 0.05 at low frequency and slightly increases to 0.35 at high frequency.

The calculated reflection loss by using the classic transmission line theory depending on the complex permittivity and permeability is shown in Fig. 3. The absorption peak is attributed to the natural ferromagnetic resonance (NFMR) of the magnetic medium given by Eq. (1) [26] and the phase cancellation (incident and reflected waves are in 180∘ out of phase) depending on the thickness of the layer.
1
$$ \omega_{0} = \gamma H_{k} $$ Here, ω 0 is the resonance frequency; γ is the gyromagnetic factor; H
k is the magnetization of the particle. For the most of the ferrites, the NFMR frequency locates at the gigahertz regime [27]. The reflection response observed in Fig. 3 can be less than −10 dB in the frequency range of 6–10 GHz with a thickness of 3 mm. It is noteworthy that the reflection loss is lower than −40 dB in the matching thickness of 2–2.5 mm at the frequency range of 9–13 GHz. The skin depth [28, 29] can be given by Eq. (2) while the conductivity at high frequency can be obtained approximately using Eq. (3).
2
$$\begin{aligned} & { \delta= \sqrt{\frac{2}{\mu_o\mu'} \sigma\omega } } \end{aligned}$$
3
$$\begin{aligned} & { \sigma = 2\pi f\varepsilon_{0}\varepsilon^{\prime\prime} } \end{aligned}$$
Fig. 3
The microwave reflection response of the single magnetic composite layer

Using the constitutive parameters measured in Fig. 2, the calculated variation of skin depth is shown in Fig. 4. The skin depth reduces from 55 to 5 mm as the frequency increases indicating that the microwave could transmit through the 3-mm magnetic layer in the whole frequency band. As a consequence of the microwave penetration, the current can be also excited on the surface of the ground metal plane.
Fig. 4
Variation of skin depth at centimeter wavelength regime for the magnetic composite layer

In order to broaden the absorption band, the cross-like structure was induced into the absorber. The cross structural metamaterial was pasted on the surface of the above-mentioned magnetic medium to adjust the permittivity and permeability, which resulted in the change of the surface impedance. The simulated results are shown in Fig. 5. The reflection curve of the unit cell (a) in Fig. 1 is given in the Fig. 5 (solid curve), whilst the dash curve is the transmission of the unit cell (b) depicting the resonance frequency of the cross resonator and the electromagnetic shield effect. There is only one peak shown in the transmission line of unit cell (b) which reveals the resonance of the cross periodic structure at the frequency of 3.7 GHz. Compared with the reflection curve the transmission power is very low, indicting that the majority of electromagnetic power is reflected at the surface of the absorber. It is noteworthy that the cross resonance frequency is slightly higher than the absorbing peak frequency in the reflection curve, which is in agreement with the results reported in [22].
Fig. 5
(a) The red solid curve is the reflection of unit cell (a) in Fig. 1, and the blue dash curve is the resonant transmission through the cross resonator array shown in unit cell (b). (b) Surface currents of the MMA at the peak absorption frequency of unit cell (a). (c) The distribution of magnetic field at 2.8 GHz. (d) The distribution of the electric field at 2.8 GHz

Compared with the reflection of the magnetic composite medium shown in Fig. 3, the absorption peak located at the 2.8 GHz in Fig. 5(a) indicates that surface impedance is adjusted successfully. The thickness ∼3 mm of the MMA structure is far less than the λ/4 at 2.8 GHz which is ∼25 mm, implying that the absorption mechanism of this structure is different from the Salisbury [30] and Jaumann [31] absorbers. The absorption mechanisms of the unit cell (a) at 2.8 GHz can be ascribed to Fabry-Pérot resonance in the space between the MMA film and ground plane. the electric and magnetic responses are artificially adjusted in the enhanced absorption at 2.8 GHz for the Ohmic loss, dielectric loss, and the coupled magnetic resonance [17]. Meanwhile, the absorption at 6.7 GHz can be attributed to the NFMR of the magnetic medium and the phase cancellation. It is noteworthy that the anti-parallel currents are observed on the MMA and the ground metal plane respectively shown in Fig. 5(b). The resonance current excited on the cross electric dipole and thus the dielectric field is distributed at the end of the cross observed in Fig. 5(d). The dielectric loss occurs at this area in every resonance cycle, whilst the Ohmic loss is mainly from the conducting region of the dipole. Spontaneously, the strong magnetic resonance fields are excited by the resonance current on the MMA and the anti-parallel current on the ground metal plane, respectively, shown in Fig. 5(c). Notably, the two above-mentioned magnetic fields are in the same direction and thus they couple in the magnetic medium. As a result, the magnetic hysteresis in the magnetic medium is generated due to the coupled magnetic resonance field in the magnetic medium. In fact, the microwave penetration depth is limited and it will be lost dramatically in the magnetic medium. So the current excited on the surface of the ground plane in our model is much smaller than that in [22], in which the cross-resonator array and a ground plane are separated by thick polyimide dielectric spacer just mechanically supporting the bi-layered metal structure. Nevertheless, anti-parallel currents are still excited on the MMA and ground metal plane. Thus the coupled resonance magnetic field is generated. Because of the magnetic medium in our work, the coupled magnetic resonance field is much weaker than that in R [22]. However, the magnetic hysteresis effects in our work enhance the loss of the electromagnetic energy. Accounted for by equivalent RLC resonate circuits, the impedance of the MMA surface at a certain frequency can be adjusted through the change of the configuration while the loss of power attributes to the Ohmic loss, scattering, and coupled magnetic field resonance.

Section1.Heading: Fabrication and experiment
Section1.Para: Based on the simulation and optimization results, the magnetic absorbing layer and MMA structure samples were fabricated. The resin matrix nano-ferroferric oxide magnetic composite was fabricated via solution mixing method and cured in a mold to form a thick layer. Then the periodic crosses were pasted on the surface of the magnetic composite layer. The free space method had also been used to test the absorption behavior of the fabricated samples including the magnetic composite absorbing layer and MMA composite structure.

The absorption performance of the tested sample is experimentally verified by measuring the complex S-parameters in a microwave anechoic chamber by a so-called free space method. The experimental setup is the same as that in [32]. Two horn antennas are connected to a vector network analyzer as the transmitter and receiver.

The measured reflectivity spectra for the magnetic absorbing layer and the MMA structure unit cell (a) are revealed in Fig. 6. There is a broadband absorption peak at 7.4 GHz in the reflectivity curve of the 3-mm magnetic composite absorber, consistent with the calculated result shown in Fig. 3. As a result of the comparison with the solid curve, there are three absorption peaks revealed in the reflectivity curve (dashed curve) of the MMA structure. The −5 dB absorption band almost covers the whole measured frequency range. Furthermore, the −10 dB absorption bandwidth is expanded by more than 100 % compared with that of the magnetic absorbing layer. In the vicinity of 2.8 GHz, an absorption peak is observed. The mechanism of this absorption is attributed to the resonance of MMA due to the anti-parallel surface currents and the coupled resonance magnetic field described above. The peak located at 6.6 GHz can be ascribed to the intrinsic absorption of the magnetic absorb medium which depends on the permittivity, permeability, and thickness of the layer. These two peaks shown in the measured curve are consistent with the simulated result shown in Fig. 5(a). It can be found that the intrinsic absorption peak for the magnetic composite in the solid curve locates at 7.4 GHz while this absorption peak for the MMA structure locates at 6.6 GHz in dashed curve. It is reasonable to attribute this to the influence of MMA and the manufacturing deviation. It is noteworthy that there is a large broadband absorption peak located at 9–15 GHz, which is totally different from the simulated result shown in Fig. 5(a). This large discrepancy between the measured and simulated results can be ascribed to the grating lobes [33] in the measuring process. Grating lobes will occur when the size of individual cross element in an array is equal to or greater than the wavelength. At high frequency in the range of the 11∼12 GHz, the operating wavelength becomes even smaller than the unit cell size. In addition, in the measurement process, the microwave is obliquely incident into the MMA structure at a small angle of 5° against the normal direction. Under this condition, the grating lobes can scatter large parts of the electromagnetic energies to a far field, and cause different reductions to the power of the simulation and measurement.
Fig. 6
Measured reflectivity spectra for the magnetic absorber layer (red solid curve) and the MMA structure (blue dashed curve)

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In summary, this paper showed the design, simulation and experimental demonstration of a metamaterial absorber based on the magnetic medium. Comparing to the magnetic composite layer, the MMA structure can evidently broaden the absorption frequency. Due to the periodicity of the cross resonator, the thickness of the proposed absorber is considerably smaller than the wavelength at the working frequency. The anti-parallel currents are observed on the surface of the MMA and the ground metal plane resulting in the coupled resonance magnetic field in the magnetic medium and the magnetic hysteresis effects generated. The designed absorption frequency is a little lower than the cross resonance frequency for the existence of the ground metal plane. The broad absorption band in the range of 9–15 GHz in the measuring curve is observed due to the grating lobes.
